p: After sequencing, the raw reads (fastq format) were firstly processed through custom Perl and Python scripts to obtain clean reads, and then a certain range of lengths was chosen from the clean reads to perform all the downstream analyses. The small RNA tags were mapped to the reference sequence by Bowtie 29 without mismatch to analyze their expression and distribution on the reference. The mapped small RNA tags were aligned to Repeat Masker, Rfam database or those types of data from the specified species itself to remove tags originating from protein-coding genes, repeat sequences, rRNA, tRNA, snRNA, and snoRNA. The remaining tags were then aligned with known miRNA and mapped to miRBase21.0 30 and modified by mirdeep2 software 31. Novel miRNA were predicted using the characteristics of the hairpin structure of the miRNA precursor, and the miREvo 32 and mirdeep2 software 31 were integrated to predict novel miRNAs through exploring the secondary structure, the Dicer cleavage site and the minimum free energy of the small RNA tags unannotated in the former steps. The known families were identified using miFam.dat ( http://www.mirbase.org/ftp.shtml) and the novel miRNA precursors were submitted to Rfam ( http://rfam.sanger.ac.uk/search/) to search for Rfam families.
